bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Landon C. Bell, June 5, 1916

div1.p: [Carter] discusses plans for a mosquito survey.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Landon C. Bell, June 5, 1916
div1.opener:
LC
June 5, 1916.
Mr. Landon Covington Bell,
115 E. Rich Street,
Columbus, Ohio.
Dear Mr. Bell:
div1.p:
I have been thinking about the mosquito survey of
Colleton and I expect a fairly satisfactory way would be for you
to take Theodore Hayne--the son of Dr. Hayne--and get him to
make the examination of Anopheles breeding in
(1) In the swamp, and
(2) in it's environment closer to the residences of
complainants.

He was working with us in July and August of last year and
knows Anopheles larvae and how to get them. He will begin work
with us again at Parr's Shoals June 15th. and should be suffi-
ciently skilled both in finding Anopheles (both larvae and the
winged insect--the imago) and in identifying them by the time
you will want him--late July or August.

He could, and it would be better for him to, develope
a number of his larvae out into imagos and keep them as exhibits,
so that there would be no question as to the species and genus
of the mosquitoes found. The same thing for winged mosquitoes
caught in houses--which he will know how to do before you need
him. On his finding of fact and these exhibits we (LePrince and
-2-
myself or any man familiar with the subject) could testify as
experts, giving the proper deductions to be made therefrom as
to whether the people at any particular residence would be be
liable, or more liable, to contract malaria from Anopheles bred
in the swamp or from those bred on their own premises, which,
I judge, is the final opinion aimed at.

Of course, if Dr. Harris is available he can both make
the survey and draw the deductions. I do not know what Dr.
Hayne's knowledge of the breeding places and the different spe-
cies of Anopheles is. he is a man of ability--decided ability--
only I don't know how much technical knowledge he has on this
particular subject. The same is true of Dr. Robert Wilson. I
shewed himIAnopheles larvae at Parr's Shoals and I have no doubt
that he would know them. Indeed, it may be worth considering to
have either him or Dr. Hayne go with Theodore Hayne. He Theodore would
know where and how to find Anopheles larvae and imagos and they
should be able to identify the different species developed and
found. Young Hayne would know anyway.

If you want Theodore Hayne please let us know as soon
as you determine on it, as we will have to fill his place. In-
deed this will be quite inconvenient, but since it would be to
his advantage we would make out temporarily: 7 to 10 or 14 days
should be longer thsn you would want him.

He will be working with Dr. T. H. D. Griffitts, “Peake's,
S. C. Care Parr Shoals Power Company”--or, of course, you could
notify his father.
